subject: Re[2]: [junit] Is there a place for private methods with TDD?

messageBody:
RJ> On Thursday, November 13, 2003, at 9:54:14 AM, Thali, Nilesh wrote:

>> IMHO, it doesn't make sense to make private methods protected simply to
>> test them. "protected" has a specific purpose in the language, and
>> unless you are expecting people to write subclasses and override those
>> methods, they probably shouldn't become protected...

RJ> So if you had a private method that needed testing, what would you do?

Find an open source Java compiler and change the symbol table lookup
code to make private variables resolve as publics.
<sorry, that was just a sick joke>

To me, there are two different tacks:
1. If your public methods are already covered with tests, you have to
stop and ask yourself why the private method needs testing at all..
isn't the testing through the public interface sufficient. If you
feel that you do need to do more testing, refactor to remove the
private method. The nicest way to do this is to create a new class
and move the method over to it as a public method. You can use the
tests that you have to verify that you did the move correctly.

2. If your public methods aren't covered with tests and you need to
test a private method, make it package-scope. This may feel weird,
but it gives you coverage and allows you to move towards a clearer
solution later.


Michael Feathers
